segments.text: When we entered the space program in the essentially early days of NASA's development, what differences do you see between then and now in terms of NASA's ideology and purpose?
Well, the actual purpose of NASA really hasn't changed.

It's a research and development organization, and as you may be aware, it grew out of the NACA, or NACA, which is the National Aeronautics Council, something that transitioned from NACA to NASA was occasioned by the
Space Act of 1958, which in turn was at least in part triggered by the success of the Soviet space program.
And from that time on, basically NASA has undertaken in the space arena to advance the state of
technology and science, and to carry out the mission for the space missions that have been deemed most appropriate by the President and other administrations including the Congress.
And of course we, following President Kennedy's commitment to put a man on the moon before the end of the decade of the 60s, put the bulk of our resources into that effort.

And then following the successful conclusion of that, it had become obviously obvious to a lot of people within NASA and presumably many people in the government that the throwaway spacecraft is an extravagant luxury and we needed to work on something that would be reusable many times,
in turn has evolved into the Shuttle Spacecraft System, which is more appropriately known as the National Space Transportation System.

And by extension, following the realization that the Shuttle would in fact be successful, Mr. Reagan wanted us to concentrate on more immediate practical applications of the Shuttle for a year or two, which was done.
And now we've embarked on building a permanent unmanned space station to be operational before the end of the decade.
It started in 84, I think, before 94 came out.
When NASA was created under Eisenhower in 58, was it intended to be a civilian type of organization, even though its first members were primary military?
Well, it was chartered.

who would handle the civilian space program of the U.S. And I would take issue with your statement that the first members of the military, because the bulk of the agency was and always has been civilian.
If you look at the Project Mercury astronauts, these basically were all military.
There were only seven people out of several thousand in the agency.

And, of course, all of the folks that had been working for NACA in the aeronautical field, that is the airfoil designers, the engine people, the ones that build and operate the wind tunnels and things of that sort, came along with the agency.
And the unmanned space program also grew up within NASA, and this was when we were totally surveying.
We probed to Jupiter and Mars, to Venus,
things like that.
So really there's only a very small percentage of military and those that are military working with NASA are basically following the civilian pursuers in their uniform.
Do you think that the sexual revolution of the 70s and the civil rights movement of the 60s have affected the attitude of NASA and the entrance of the minorities into the space program?
Well, I guess you'd have to say that

to the extent that these things have affected the sociology of the United States in general, they have also affected the sociology of NASA specifically, we are finding that we can now obtain, for example, in the minority, racial minority category, racial minorities that have gained flight training and test pilot experience in the military,
and are available to enter into the NASA program were back in the early 60s, there were not such people anywhere in the military or in the U.S. social structure.
We were also finding quite a number of women engineers, scientists, medical doctors, things of this sort, and you're starting to see women as pilots in the armed forces
and flying for the commercial airlines.
And I would imagine that before too many years are out, like, we'll have some selected pilot category within NASA also.
Can you check this real quick?
Yeah, I think that will work.
Were women and minorities brought in gradually, or as you said, since there weren't too many in the 60s, was there a sudden push to bring them in?
There was not a sudden push, but by the same token, they weren't brought in gradually either.
I came into the program in 66, and there was one selection of 11 scientists in 67, and we got a few of the NOL, the Mandorbin Laboratory guys,
when their program was canceled.
But basically, between 1967 and 1978, 11 years, there were no new inputs into the astronaut corps.
And what happened in 1978, we selected a total of 30 people, as they would call it, including six women and several racial minorities.
And in the intervening 11 years,
the texture of our social fabric had changed quite a bit.

And additionally, we were looking at selecting people specifically in career patterns, i.e., as mission specialists, having created that billet, and looking at a spacecraft which was big enough to carry more than just the two or three that were required to fly it,
We recently completed a Mission 7 on board, the 41G mission, and there's one Schedule 8 on board about a year from now.
So you're getting to the point where you can afford to have a lot of differentiation in terms of duties and experience.
It just seemed that's the way the situation fell out.
In what ways do you think that women and minorities have added or
maybe subtracted from the NASA program?
Well, I think probably the biggest way that they've added is just by showing the American people that we've got a real cross-section of the population involved.
You can't help but feel that you're getting more support from areas representing racial minorities and women's groups and things of this sort, and they see one of their own up there.
participating and doing a good job.
As you're probably aware, a tremendous demand for talks by and interviews with Sally Ride and some of the other folks.
In fact, that's a bit of a personal hardship on her, and she's been relieved that Judy Resnick and some of the other folks wouldn't have gotten up to help share the load.
Oh, that's good.
I think it may also be interesting to look back and you note that the Soviets were the first to put a woman in space, Valentina Tereshkova.
They made sure that she was up there by herself, but the technology basically was a one-person capsule at the time.
And until we announced in, it must have been March of 82,
When Sally arrived with me going up on a space shuttle flight, they had absolutely no interest discernible in having any more women in space.
Immediately after Sally was selected and announced, we started getting questions along the lines of, why do you want to put a woman into space?
We've already done it once.
And so basically the implication being that was all that mattered.
And what are her qualifications?
What's she going to do up there?

And then there was a long silence, and in August of 82, that is about five months later, during the Unispace conference in Austria, they had arranged to have a TV downlink to the conference, and all of a sudden they announced, by the way, Svetlana Savitskaya, for the glory of Mother Russia, and all that sort of thing, is the
a crew member in the current Soyuz crew going up to the Soyuz would have a Beamer message down to the assembled delegates.
So they were very anxious that the United States might be perceived as affording greater opportunities to humankind than they were.
And then again this spring, when it was, I don't know, I guess it was about a year ago when it was announced that the Soyuz was going up again,
Kathy Charlton would be performing in the spacewalk, the EVA.

We didn't hear anything from them, but you notice about July of this year, they made a point of sending Svetlana Savitskaya up a second time, thereby getting the title of the first woman to go into space twice, and they sent her outside on the spacewalk, just so they could claim that the first spacewalk by a woman was done by a Soviet cosmonaut, and they're very interested in maintaining this sort of
Guinness World Record statute on things.
They don't have anything like the MMU do they?

No, they've been interested in that too and we were privately a little bit apprehensive that there might be some effort underway to say a month before our flight back in February to do something that would claim to be an MMU flight but they didn't.
STS-5 was

The first shuttle flight to deploy a satellite, they did deploy two communications satellites, but about three months or two months before that, the Soviets made a point of deploying a satellite from the Soviet.
As we can tell, it was something that opened the hatch, and they pushed it out, and they deployed a satellite.

If you read their version of the history books, I think you will probably find that they claimed to have deployed the first sub-satellite or artificial satellite from a space station or a space group.
Well, after your flight, I read a newspaper article that said that the Russians had said that the flight was an overall failure because of several malfunctions, but they overlooked the MMU flight.
How do you feel about that?
We did have some problems, but let me take them one or two at a time.
You've got to bear in mind that the shuttle, being a space transportation system, is just that.

The two communications satellites were privately owned, and in order to get from the shuttle altitude to the geosynchronous or geostationary altitude that is used for communications relay satellites, you basically need
two additional motors or burns to boost the satellite up, first into an elliptic motor and into a circular motor, 22,300.

And the satellite manufacturer, Hughes, provides the second motor as an integral part of it and contracted with McDonnell Douglas to provide the first stage motor as a proprietary launch system that he's purchased from
certified by McDonnell-Lewis, and basically the role of the shuttle is to carry this assembly into orbit, point it in the right direction, and deploy it at the specified time, all of which we did.

The problem that prevented the two satellites from getting into orbit was that the throat of the nozzle in the first stage motor that was the McDonnell-Lewis thing deteriorated and blew out after about 18 seconds.
into a planned 80-some second burn.
So they got only a fraction of the velocity.
And it was very consistent, too, because they both wound up in essentially similar orbits, about 150 by 600.
So to the extent that, if you'll pardon my using the skydiving analogy, that if a skydiver's parachute doesn't open, he's going to hold the power to the plane responsible.

uh we don't feel that nasa was responsible for the failures but we acknowledge that you've got to consider in the context of the overall system there was a problem at the same time we were anxious to in the next mission 51a is going to go up there and try to retrieve these two satellites and bring them back for refurbishment so you can at least say that
Things launched on expendable launch vehicles like the Ariane or the Delta tend to wind up at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean.
No problem over there, is there?
Things launched out of the shuttle tend to be in orbit because you're already in orbit when you deploy them.
Okay.
You were admitted to NASA in the period following the launches of Sputniks 1 and 2.
This time might be called the American race for space.
What do you feel was the emotional tone of that period?

um before we had our before we landed on the moon well when i came in which is in 66 eight years after uh well almost nine years after the first sputnik i wouldn't say that we really had a a race for space mentality we were more concerned about the the timetable that had been agreed to i.e man on the moon when we turned before the end of 69
and the efforts were bent more towards working against the calendar than they were racing with the Russians.
We heard at one time that they were interested in sending manned spacecraft to the Moon, and we didn't hear any more about that.
When the actual Apollo 11 occasion did come around, they were most cooperative.
They had Luna 16 in orbit.
around the moon.
This was an unmanned reconnaissance or photographic probe.

They contacted us in the control center and offered to do anything that was necessary to keep Luna 16 out of the way of Apollo 11, because they didn't want to shoulder the responsibility for any sort of problems with the lunar landing or returns.
I thought that President Kennedy had kind of a grudge match going with the Russians about the space race.
That was the impression I received over the years.
I don't think you can call it a grudge match.
One of the things that I think is interesting and useful in the international arena is that
In undertakings in space, basically, whenever the players are competing against natural obstacles, it's a situation where there really aren't any losers.
If we win and get the man to the moon and back, basically, we've done so as representatives of humanity.
It's not really a matter of, hey, we beat the Russians and now let's see what other events we can

You notice that during Apollo 11 there was worldwide non-political interest just in the fact that, hey, here's some people that happen to be Americans that are up there really walking around on the moon.
And even the Soviets applauded that.
Well, how do you view Russia's involvement in space, and do you think that they have added valuable technology to our space program, or have we aided them?
Well, I can't say that I'm aware of any technology that we've just gotten from the Russians.
My general assessment, and I caution you that it's just a general one, is that our program is
technologically superior and more sophisticated than the Soviet program.
However, they have a national commitment to applying the things that they have developed, specifically the Soyuz and the Soyuz space station.
They apparently are willing to manufacture Soyuz spacecraft in
fairly large numbers so they can go and use them.

And with the Salyut, their space station, the first one of which was put up in 71, Salyut 1, I think it was 71, they've had essentially a continuous stream of these space stations up there, presumably getting slightly larger and with more equipment on them.
Recently they had a crew of three continuously aloft for 238 days.
They're very interested in the physiology of long-term exposure to weightlessness.
Some people take this as a sign that they are working very hard to be able to put a man or a man in orbit around Mars first.

When you look at a Mars mission, for any economical propellant scenario, generally it's going to take you about a year to get there and about a year to get back, so you need to understand what is involved in either providing artificial gravity or enabling the human body to withstand weightlessness for a period of about two years and then readapt to
gravity when you get back here.
They had a great deal of trouble.
I understand they couldn't walk forwell, they're still having trouble walking now after that period of non-weightlifting.
Well, I confess I really haven't gotten any details on that, but the guys that were up for 211 days, the previous bunch, didn't seem to have any trouble at all with happening.
Our philosophy from Skylab experience has been that if the individuals involved
exercise diligently every day and keep in shape, you probably won't have any difficulties.
What was the other part?
Oh, have they gotten anything from us?
I guess we would have to say that they appear to have gotten some things from us.
They have copied some of our operational techniques.

Prior to the Apollo-Soyuz mission, their control center was a mysterious place, and they announced in the newspapers, after their cosmonauts were in orbit, by the way, yesterday they were launched and they were doing well and happy.
I hope you learned a lot about public relations in the Apollo-Soyuz mission, because now they've televised some of their launches, they show pictures of the inside of the control center,
keep their own citizenry at least a lot more involved in what's going on.
Additionally, it appears that the Soviets are building something that looks like a space shuttle.
You see pictures and reports in Aviation Week and various other sources
It may be that they're attempting to copy the space shuttle technology.
Their approach is more to the shuttle than just the exterior configuration, so it'll be interesting to see how they do with that.
Russia has had people of other nations fly with them on space missions.
Do you see America doing the same in the future?
Well, we already have.
Oh, yeah?
In November of last year,
On the first space lab mission, we had a West German payload specialist, Ulf Merbold, representing ESA, the European Space Agency, as a crew member.
And on this last flight, 41G, we had a Canadian naval officer, Martin Garneau, on board as a payload specialist.
There are a lot more in the offing.
The situation, I'm chagrined to say, has gotten to the point where I can no longer keep track of all the crew assignments and who's on what.
But we have commitments to, or have extended offers to, oh boy, China, Brazil, Australia, Saudi Arabia, and I think Argentina, but I'm not sure.
But in total, about a dozen different countries have their crew members fly on the shuttle, and we are actively seeking international participation in the space station program.
It's expected that the Japanese will build a module to go on the space station, and the European Space Agency, ESA, is expected to participate, and the Canadian Government will probably
manipulator arm for the space station as they did the manipulator arm for the shuttle.
Has President Reagan's administration affected NASA's budget or overall purpose?
Well, I think Mr. Reagan has been very supportive of the first space shuttle.
Obviously, it was
already well underway when he came into office, but he recognized the potential of the system and the need to continue the funding to continue the development on it.
And my opinion is that he was initially reluctant to commit additional money to do things beyond applying the space shuttle, and then he was convinced of the utility of the space station
basically endorsed it, gave the go-ahead back in January during the State of the Union speech.

And although it is not a NASA program, he has recently initiated this so-called Strategic Defense Initiative for Star Wars project within the Air Force to see if there is a way, using the space vantage point of the space technology, to get out of this assured mutual destruction
our mutually assured destruction stalemate between ourselves and the Soviet Union.
Well, my next question is about the Star Wars defense.
Does NASA have any plans to aid President Reagan in developing a space defense program for Star Wars?
MR. No.
Getting back to one of the previous questions, NASA is a civilian space agency.
There is also a fairly large military space program, as you're probably aware, administered by the Air Force, but with involvement from other services and other governmental agencies.
And the Strategic Defense Initiative is strictly a military air force program and is being carried out by them.
Lieutenant General James Abrahamson, who was
associate administrator for manned spaceflight at NASA for a couple of years.
He was heading up the Strategic Defense Initiative.
He's an Air Force officer, and his responsibility prior to coming to NASA was as the program manager of the F-16 fighter program, so it's certainly in keeping with his background.
What do you think of President Reagan's plans to have people such as poets, musicians, teachers, and businessmen go into space with you and observe?
Well, the basic philosophy arose out of a recognition that on every space shuttle flight, we had seats for at least seven people, and that we were generally not filling them up
with professional and these seats could be filled at very small additional cost since they were going on anyway.

And it was recognized that since the American taxpayer is paying for the basic shuttle program and subsidizing the flights, although we're getting a lot of the operating expenses back from the commercial users now, that we might as well look around and
and see if we couldn't carry some American citizens to share the experience.

The charter of NASA under the Space Act of 1958 is sufficiently broad to allow us to do things like this, with the justification being the dissemination of knowledge and the advancement of technology and the state of the art in the space program.
And it was more a matter of determining how you would

select people like this so that the American public was generally supportive of the fact that Mrs. so-and-so or Mr. so-and-so or Dr. somebody or other was going up instead of wondering why in the world the agency picked a person like that.
The system was set up to allow us to carry journalists
poets, artists, executives or managers from private industry, as well as the middle levels of the government, educators.
And with Mr. Reagan's selection of an educator, secondary school or elementary teacher, which is his call as the chief executive to be the first one, gave the program 100% green light.
We're looking forward to seeing somebody in about a year to come fly with us.
Will they have to go through a certain program to get ready for the flight?
Yeah.
We don't think it'll be a very elaborate program, probably about two months or maybe a little longer.
One of the primary things you would like to assure yourself of in any sort of training program like this is that in the event that there is some sort of a
a crisis situation on board the shuttle.

That individual will not get hysterical and go to pieces or try to do something rash, but he'll be content to stay out of the way, strap in a seat or something, and let the crew handle the problem, getting all panicky.
And then, of course, they will trade him for whoever
in operating some of the facilities in the Shuttle, that we can be an independent person and not have to rely on the food for everything.
Using the manned mobile unit, or the MMU, you were the world's first human satellite.
How did you feel at the time?

The feeling was more of a release than anything else in that I had been working on the program for quite a number of years, and we had had troubles with the two communication systems, like sanitation and inflatable run of the balloon.
And in some of the previous missions, the guys had trouble even getting the pressure set to work properly.
You know, we were somewhat apprehensive.
There might be something come up that would either cancel the EVAs or bring the whole mission back early or something like that.
So close and yet so far.
